<summary>
1. The invention describes a gate valve for controlling the dispensing of viscous substances from flexible bags or pouches, allowing one-handed operation and easy cleaning.
2. The valve consists of a tubular sleeve with a dispensing passage and a gate valve guide member, which carries a reciprocating gate.
3. The gate and guide are curved complementally transversely, allowing effective sealing when closed and no obstruction when fully opened.
4. The gate valve member is reciprocated on the guide member by an integral extension, which has flat-finger and split lugs for engagement with the guide plate.
5. The valve assembly is mounted on the spout of a bag, which is supported in a dispenser, and can be locked in place by the dispenser's housing.
6. The gate valve can be opened and closed using one hand, providing gradual or quick flow control, and can be easily disassembled for cleaning.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The text describes a vehicle rearview mirror system that can be used with various types of vehicles, irrespective of the protocol of the reverse-gear indication signal. (3 sentences)
2. The system includes a mirror control that receives an input from a vehicle control and determines the protocol of the output based on monitoring the output and attempting to conclude its state. (3 sentences)
3. The output of the vehicle control may be gear status information, engine information, alarm information, or door status information. The mirror control attempts to conclude a state of the output based on the type of information. (3 sentences)
4. The mirror control may include a microcomputer with software that determines the protocol by software processing and monitors the output of the vehicle control upon starting and running. (3 sentences)
5. The system includes at least one light sensor, and the mirror control establishes a value for the drive signal in response to an output of the light sensor. (3 sentences)
6. The vehicle rearview mirror system includes an electro-optic reflective element and a controller that establishes a reflectance level of the reflective element in response to the reverse-gear indication and its protocol. (3 sentences)
7. The controller determines the protocol of the reverse-gear indication by software processing and monitors the reverse-gear indication upon starting and during running. (3 sentences)
8. The controller may maintain reverse-inhibit-running and reverse-inhibit-ignition-cycle parameters to help determine the protocol of the reverse-gear indication. (3 sentences)

</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention describes an anti-lock braking system for motorcycles with an anti-dive device and a damped telescopic front suspension.
2. The anti-dive device responds to the brake force applied to the front wheel and prevents the front fork from diving during braking, reducing the decrease in braking efficiency.
3. The anti-dive unit employs a hydraulic pump and a modulator to control the hydraulic pressure to the front wheel brake, and a pressure discharge valve and a sensor to detect the nearly-locked condition of the front wheel.
4. The anti-dive unit is integrated into the hydraulic pipe between the master cylinder and the front wheel brake, and the cooperation between the anti-lock control unit and the anti-dive device improves the anti-lock braking system's efficiency and reduces chassis vibration.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The text describes an improved partition system for dividing cargo areas in refrigerated trailers, allowing for multi-temperature transport.
2. The system includes at least two panels that can be moved independently using mounting assemblies.
3. In one embodiment, two bulkheads or panels are slidably attached to separate pairs of ceiling-mounted rails, enabling the definition of multiple cargo areas.
4. Another embodiment features half-width bulkheads that are releasably secured to one another and independently, slidably attached to the trailer ceiling.
5. The panels are slidably attached to rails using a trolley assembly and can be raised and secured to the ceiling when not in use.
6. The rail system includes longitudinal rails with internal channels for receiving rollers, end rails with lift mechanisms and safety chains, and mounting flanges for fastening to the trailer walls or ceiling.
7. The panels can be modified to use various mounting mechanisms and rail configurations, allowing for different panel movements and mounting positions.
</summary>

The text describes an improved partition system for dividing cargo areas in refrigerated trailers, allowing for multi-temperature transport. The panels are slidably attached to rails using a trolley assembly and can be raised and secured to the ceiling when not in use. The rail system includes longitudinal rails with internal channels for receiving rollers, end rails with lift mechanisms and safety chains, and mounting flanges for fastening to the trailer walls or ceiling. The panels can be modified to use various mounting mechanisms and rail configurations, allowing for different panel movements and mounting positions.

<summary>
1. The text describes an invention related to a sanitizable rotary valve for use in liquid chromatography systems, specifically for separating and purifying biological macromolecules in the pharmaceutical industry.
2. Prior art rotary valves, such as those in U.S. Pat. Nos. 4,808,317, 2,985,589, 3,268,604, and 4,409,033, have been used for fluid distribution but lack sanitizable features. Known non-rotary sanitizable valves include those in U.S. Pat. Nos. 4,757,834, 4,687,015, 4,921,015, and 5,273,075.
3. The invention is a rotary carousel diaphragm valve with a thermoplastic elastomeric diaphragm integrally molded to form multiple sealing ports of the rotor face. The diaphragm has ports or grooves molded into its face to sealably engage grooves or ports in the stator face and form sanitary elastomeric tubular ducts leading through the body of the rotor.
4. The rotor and stator have at least two inner surfaces, including a rotor having a body with a stator-facing surface, a stator having a body with a rotor-facing surface, and means for at least one SIP/barrier gutter located on an inner surface of the valve. Orthogonal actuating means are used to incrementally adjust the rotor perpendicular to its direction of linear motion.
5. The invention also includes a multi-port sliding valve with a linear slider, a stator having a plurality of connection ports and associated channels in liquid communication with external fluid sources and separation means, and at least one connection port capable of being in fluid communication with a source of SIP fluid. Orthogonal separation means are used for partially separating the slider body from the stator body, allowing flushing of sanitizing fluid across the stator face without loss of fluid to the outside.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to gas-liquid contacting trays and improvements in valve-tray assemblies. One aspect of the invention includes an improved tray valve assembly for a process column, which comprises a plurality of apertures formed in the tray having a valve cover mounted thereon. The valve cover is mounted by first and second legs, the first leg being disposed to intercept the flow of liquid across the tray and being wider than the second leg. The legs are mounted to the tray in outwardly slotted portions thereof for defining the orientation of the valve relative to the liquid flow.
2. Another aspect of the invention includes the above-described tray valve being formed of a round disc having the first and second legs depending downwardly therefrom. Each of the legs are formed with outwardly extending flange portions for underlying the tray and locking the disc in a floating relationship relative thereto. The valve aperture is circular in shape and the valve legs are disposed in slotted regions disposed outwardly of the circular aperture to prevent the rotation of the valve plate for maintaining the orientation of the valve leg relative to the tray. The biasing means comprises a detent portion formed on the cover of the valve for preventing the surface thereof from resting flush against the tray surface, facilitating the initial passage of vapor through the valve.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is a fluid pressure regulator assembly that generates power while regulating fluid pressure.
2. It reduces variances in output pressure caused by large differences in input pressure.
3. The assembly is inexpensive to manufacture and maintain, and is lightweight and portable.
4. The invention allows the use of a smaller or more inexpensive regulator by extracting work from the pressurized fluid before it enters the regulator.
5. The assembly can utilize various types of motors and generators, and can be used in various applications such as gas grills, underwater breathing apparatuses, and vehicles.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to pallet systems, specifically those that facilitate loading and unloading while limiting the shifting of loaded items. Pallets are used to transport loads of one or more items, which can be smaller items packaged into larger units.
2. The pallet system includes a pallet with raised parallel guide rails and a pallet cap that fits onto the pallet base to form the pallet. Each tray has side supports that straddle a pair of guide rails, restricting lateral movement. The pallet system also includes end plates that help secure the load and protect the ends of the trays.
3. The pallet base is a conventional pallet with pockets that elevate the top surface and provide recesses for handling. The pallet cap has pockets customized to fit within the pallet base pockets, providing support and positioning.
4. The pallet cap has raised, parallel guide rails that help position trays, interlock adjacent trays, and restrict lateral movement. The top surface of the pallet cap is open between the guide rails, enabling open space for packing items. End stops can be positioned at the outer edges of each pair of guide rails to limit longitudinal movement.
5. End plates are vertically positioned at the front and back ends of the pallet and held in position by notches at the ends of each guide rail. End plates can be shaped to complement the contours of the trays and nest within one another when not in use.
6. The pallet system can be made of various materials, such as plastic, and manufactured using methods like thermo forming, rotomolding, or injection molding. The pallet system can be customized for its intended load, such as egg trays, by adjusting the size, shape, and position of the guide rails, end stops, and end plates.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes an electrical driven flying saucer based on magnetic suspension, which includes a saucer shell, a saucer cabin, a rotary-wing system, and a control system. The rotary-wing system is a magnetic suspension electromotive rotary-wing system with magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels, an electromotive ring, a magnetic suspension shaft, and a magnetic suspension guide rail.
2. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended on the magnetic suspension shaft using magnetic suspension radial and axial bearings, and the electromotive ring and magnetic suspension shaft form a magnetic suspension electric engine.
3. The text also suggests two improvements: coaxial axial dual magnetic suspension electromotive rotary wings and coaxial radial dual magnetic suspension electromotive rotary wings, which help overcome the reactive torque of the rotary wings and enhance the power performance of the flying saucer.
4. The magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels are suspended using magnetic forces between the magnetic suspension inner ring and the magnetic suspension shaft, and between the magnetic suspension outer ring and the magnetic suspension outer ring guide rail.
5. The magnetic suspension electric engine is designed according to general motor principles, with the electromotive ring acting as a stator, the magnetic suspension rotary-wing wheels as a rotor, and the magnetic suspension shaft as a spindle. </summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention concerns streptavidin muteins, a process for their production, and their use for the isolation, purification, and determination of biological substances, particularly recombinant proteins.
2. The importance of the biotin/streptavidin system in molecular biology has increased significantly due to its high affinity and specificity. However, its use is limited to biotinylated proteins or peptides.
3. To extend the application range of the biotin/streptavidin system, peptide ligands have been developed that bind to streptavidin with high affinity. These peptide ligands can be genetically fused to proteins, allowing their purification and detection without the need for biotinylation.
4. The present invention optimizes the streptavidin/peptide ligand system by producing streptavidin muteins with improved binding affinity. This is achieved through mutations in the region of amino acid positions 44 to 53 of streptavidin.
5. The streptavidin muteins of the present invention have a higher binding affinity for peptide ligands than wild-type streptavidin, enabling more efficient purification and detection of recombinant proteins.
6. The invention also provides methods for producing, purifying, and using the streptavidin muteins, as well as vectors and cells for their expression. The advantages of the streptavidin mutein/peptide ligand system include mild elution conditions, increased binding strength, and the ability to purify and detect non-biotinylated proteins.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes methods for forming substituted guanidines using nickel catalysts in the presence of guanylating agents and amines or pyrrolidines.
2. Nickel catalysts, preferably in the zero oxidation state, are derived from nickel-boride alloys, nickel-phosphide alloys, aluminum-nickel alloys, nickel on kieselguhr, and nickel on silica/alumina.
3. Suitable guanylating agents are thioureas and isothioureas, with at least one R group being a protecting group, such as Boc, Cbz, or arylsulfonyl groups.
4. The reactions are carried out at temperatures from -30 to 140°C, preferably at room temperature or under ambient conditions, in solvent systems such as DMF, THF, DMSO, or water.
5. The reactions result in high yields (at least 10%, preferably 40%, and more preferably 85%) after short reaction times (30 minutes for thioureas and 2 hours for isothioureas).
6. The methods can be used to synthesize N-substituted and N,N-disubstituted guanidines from bis-protected thioureas, mono-, di-, tri-, and tetrasubstituted guanidines from N-protected thioureas, and aliphatic and aromatic amines.
7. Nickel catalysts are advantageous due to their relatively inexpensive cost, complete recoverability, and ability to promote guanylation reactions via a mechanism similar to that described by Ni et al. (J. Org. Chem. 56:4035-42, 1991).
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for continuously electrolytically coloring aluminum strips or wires, involving anodic oxidation and electrolytic coloring without requiring a large amount of electrical energy or direct connection to a power source.
2. The anodic oxidation bath forms an oxide film on the aluminum strip or wire, which is then electrolytically colored in a bath containing a specific acid or water-soluble metal salt to produce a colored anodic coating with excellent weatherability or fade resistance.
3. The anodic oxidation bath composition includes an aqueous solution of sulfuric acid, and the thickness of the oxide film formed is preferably between 4 to 15 microns for room temperature anodization or up to 25 microns for high-temperature anodization.
4. The electrolytic coloring bath contains at least one of a nickel salt, a cobalt salt, a copper salt, a tin salt, or selenious acid, and the bath composition and conditions determine the color obtained, ranging from yellow-brown to black brown or yellow to redish orange.
5. The aluminum strip or wire is passed successively through a degreasing bath, an etching bath, a current supply bath, an anodic oxidation bath, an electrolytic coloring bath, and a sealing bath, with the current supply bath optional and the electrolytic conditions controlled by immersion period or area.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes a process for assembling a DNA sequence of interest in plants for stable integration using two or more precursor vectors through site-specific DNA recombination.
2. The process can be performed using various site-specific recombinases/integrases, such as PhiC31 integrase, and the choice of promoter for expressing the recombinase affects the efficiency of assembly and recovery of primary transformants.
3. The precursor vectors can be delivered to plants using various methods, including Agrobacterium-mediated transformation, particle bombardment, or other techniques.
4. The choice of transformation method depends on the plant species and the desired outcome, with Agrobacterium-mediated transformation being a preferred method for dicotyledonous plants.
5. The process allows for the optimization and identification of a desired DNA sequence of interest for stable nuclear transformation of plant cells, enabling detailed study of gene functions and avoiding difficult cloning procedures.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention involves a process for assembling a DNA sequence of interest in plants using two or more precursor vectors through site-specific DNA recombination.
2. The process can be performed using various site-specific recombinases/integrases, such as PhiC31 integrase, and the choice of promoter for expressing the recombinase affects the efficiency of assembly and recovery of primary transformants.
3. The precursor vectors can be delivered to plants using various methods, including Agrobacterium-mediated transformation, particle bombardment, or other techniques. Agrobacterium-mediated transformation is preferred for dicotyledonous plants.
4. The process allows for the optimization and identification of a desired DNA sequence of interest for stable nuclear transformation of plant cells, enabling detailed study of gene functions and avoiding difficult cloning procedures.
5. The assembly of a T-DNA region containing a functional BAR gene through PhiC31 integrase-mediated recombination is a preferred embodiment of the invention.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a swash plate type compressor with an aluminum swash plate coated with a heat curable, cross-linked coating of a polyfluoro elastomer bonded directly to the aluminum, a lubricious additive, and a load bearing additive. This coating allows the use of low silicon alloy aluminum without the need for metal plating or high finish polishing.
2. The coating is applied by spraying an unlinked polyfluoro elastomer onto the roughened surfaces of the swash plate and then curing it in an oven at an elevated temperature. The coating is preferred to have a thickness of approximately 0.0012 inches (30 μm) and a ratio of 70% liquid portion to 30% solid portion.
3. The coating provides both durability and low coefficient of friction, enabling the use of lower cost, low silicon aluminum base material for the swash plate. The coating process does not require the high surface finish or complex electroplating process used in prior swash plate designs.
4. The coating has been shown to increase the seizure loads and reduce the friction coefficient of swash plates compared to uncoated and tin-coated swash plates. The coating also eliminates the need for metal coatings or hypereutectic base materials, as the load bearing additives do not require high surface finish metals such as tin and zinc.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides organic polymers suitable for use in anti-reflective coatings on semiconductor devices, specifically for use in photolithography processes using 193 nm (ArF) and 248 nm (KrF) light beams. These polymers absorb light strongly at specific wavelengths to prevent the standing wave effect and light reflection, and eliminate rear diffraction and reflected light from lower layers. The polymers are designed to form a cross-linked structure and can be prepared from polyhydroxystyrene resin, poly(styrene-acrylate) resin, or novolac resin using diazonaphthoquinone halide and an amine in a solvent such as tetrahydrofuran, toluene, benzene, methylethylketone, or dioxane. The polymers have proven to be excellent organic anti-reflective coating materials during the formation of submicro-patterns in photolithographic processes.
2. The present invention also provides anti-reflective coating compositions containing these polymers and preparation methods thereof. The compositions can be prepared by dissolving a polymer in an organic solvent and adding one or more light-absorbing compounds selected from anthracene and its derivatives, fluorenone derivatives, fluorene and its derivatives, fluorenol, xanthone, quinizarin, and fluorescein. The organic solvent used for the preparation can be any suitable conventional organic solvent, and the amount of solvent used is preferably 200-5000% (w/w) with respect to the weight of the polymer used. An anti-reflective coating can be provided on a semiconductor silicon wafer by filtering a solution of a polymer or composition, coating the filtered solution or composition on a wafer, and hard-baking the coating to cross-link the anti-reflective coating polymer. The polymers form a cross-linked structure when they are coated on a wafer and baked at high temperatures, allowing them to form an organic anti-reflective coating material which is spectroscopically stable under conventional photolithographic conditions. <summary>
1. The text describes an invention of a white, flame-retardant, UV-resistant, thermoformable, oriented film made from a crystallizable thermoplastic with a thickness between 10 and 350 μm.
2. The film comprises at least one white pigment, one flame retardant, and one UV absorber, and has good orientability and thermoformability, as well as excellent optical and mechanical properties.
3. The invention aims to provide a cost-effective solution for producing such a film, which can be used in various industries, including construction and advertising.
4. The film passes fire tests to DIN 4102 Part 2 and Part 1, and the UL 94 test, making it suitable for low-flammability materials.
5. The film exhibits high UV resistance, maintaining its color and mechanical properties after prolonged outdoor use.
6. The film can be produced using known processes, with the flame retardant and UV absorber added as masterbatches, and precrystallized or predried before extrusion.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes various methods for producing 143a (1,1,1-trifluoroethane) using hydrofluorination of 1,1-difluoro-1-chloroethane (142b) in a gas phase reaction with hydrofluoric acid (HF).
2. The text discusses several patents and examples of previous methods for producing 143a, including the use of catalysts such as iron hydroxide and rare earth oxide, arsenic trifluoride and antimony pentafluoride, chromium (III) chloride on alumina, and bismuth on alumina.
3. The text introduces a new method for producing 143a using a Cr catalyst, which can be unsupported or supported, in the presence or absence of a cocatalyst such as nickel, cobalt, or manganese salts. This method achieves high conversion and selectivity for 143a, with minimal formation of unwanted by-products.
4. The text provides several examples of the new method, including the use of CrF 3 .4H 2  O or Cr/Ni/AlF 3  as the catalyst, and the ability to handle feedstocks containing impurities such as 141b and HCl without significant deactivation of the catalyst.
5. The text also discusses the importance of maintaining the correct HF/142b ratio to avoid olefin formation and the ability to remove low levels of olefinic materials from 143a using a separate post-reactor containing the same catalyst. The text also mentions the potential for using the process at high pressure.
</summary>

<summary>
1. This invention relates to an improved process for the preparation of pyrazolotriazoles using hypophosphorous acid in the deacylation and desulfurization step.
2. Pyrazolotriazoles are useful magenta couplers for photographic products but are difficult to synthesize. The most common method involves the desulfurization of triazolothiadiazines.
3. The desulfurization process generates unwanted impurities, including thione and disulfide, which can interfere with subsequent reaction steps and are detrimental in photographic systems.
4. Hypophosphorous acid reduces the amount of these impurities and increases the yield of the desired product. It also forms H2S as a by-product, which is readily removed.
5. The process involves reacting an acylated compound with an aqueous mixture of hypophosphorous acid and hydrochloric or hydrobromic acid to produce hydrogen sulfide and pyrazolotriazole.
6. The process generates less sulfur and sulfur-containing organic impurities than when no hypophosphorous acid is present.
7. Compounds used as starting materials and intermediates, as well as the desired products, all contain inert substituents, which are stable, non-reactive, and do not prevent the formation of the compound.
8. The process is conducted at a temperature within the range of from about 20° C. to about 200° C., in the substantial absence of water, and with a catalytic quantity of a Bronsted or Lewis acid.
9. The reaction time is dependent on the reaction conditions and inherent reactivity of the reactants, and is usually complete in from about 0.5 to about 24 hours.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes an invention for forming fiber mixtures from multiple fiber types using a method that sequentially takes partial quantities from individual fiber bales.
2. The method eliminates the disadvantages of the prior art by measuring the entire momentary quantity of each fiber lot before each pass and removing only the calculated partial quantity from the measured fiber lot.
3. This approach ensures that all fiber bales are opened without residual fibers and allows for an optimally homogeneous mixture.
4. The method also sets a predetermined period for the removal of each partial quantity to maintain a determined time schedule and prevent idle run of processing machines.
5. The apparatus for performing the method includes a bale opener, a quantity measuring device, and a control device that controls the opener based on signals from the measuring device.
6. The height-measuring device is a preferred choice for the quantity measuring device as it allows for simple and accurate determination of partial fiber quantities based on the height of the fiber bale.
7. The control device determines the precise partial quantities to be removed and controls the fiber removing operation, including the displacement of the transporting device and the beginning and end of the bale opening operation.
8. The invention can be applied to various types of fiber removing apparatus and quantity measuring devices, and the method can be used to make mixtures of constant quantity proportions while maintaining a uniform delivery schedule.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for forming bias laid, non-woven fabrics with yarns in at least two layers laid at an angle of 30° to 150° to the long axis of the fabric. The yarns in the layers are held together by stitching or other external means, such as adhesive bonding. The fabric formation process involves a series of layers that are held together for storage, shipment, and ultimate impregnation.
2. The invention improves upon prior art non-woven fabrics by allowing fully parallel courses of bias laid, non-woven fabrics to be placed on moving conveyors with partial overlapping of return courses. The rake mechanism, synchronized with but driven separately from the conveyors, yarn carrying means, and bonding mechanism, accepts and retains yarns between or on the needles of the rake mechanism, ensuring parallelism and enabling successive courses to overlie a portion of an already laid course for better control of strength and thickness. The rake mechanism can move a full or fractional course opposite the direction of movement of the fabric forming mechanism, allowing for varying degrees of overlap and fabric density.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for inserting different weft threads in a multiple-color air jet loom, allowing stable weft insertion with suitable weft carrying forces for each thread.
2. In prior looms, air under uniform pressure is ejected from groups of main nozzles and subnozzles, resulting in constant weft carrying forces and varying weft thread speeds. The present invention addresses this issue by producing different weft carrying forces for each thread.
3. In the first embodiment (FIG. 1), subnozzles are divided into groups with different pitches and spacings, allowing the subnozzle group closer to the warp shed to produce a larger weft carrying force.
4. In the second embodiment (FIG. 2), subnozzles have different orifice diameters or are supplied with air under different pressures to produce varying weft carrying forces.
5. In the third embodiment (FIG. 3), directional control valves selectively supply air under pressure to different subnozzle groups. In the fourth and sixth embodiments (FIGS. 4 and 8), weft insertion main nozzles and subnozzles are supplied with air under different pressures. The fifth embodiment (FIG. 6) uses a remotely controlled pressure regulator valve to regulate air pressure.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a process for spinning bast fibres, which includes health preserving, opening, cleaning, carding, and spinning the fibres to produce bast fibre yarn. The health preservation step is crucial for improving the flexibility and spinnability of bast fibres, reducing end breakage rate, and enhancing work efficiency and product quality. The process can be applied to various bast fibres such as jute, kenaf, and hemp, and the weight percentage of jute fibres in the bast fibres can range from 20% to 100%.
2. The invention also includes a process for blended spinning bast fibres and other fibres, which involves health preserving the bast fibres, blending them with other fibres, opening, cleaning, carding, and spinning the blended fibres to produce multi-fibre yarn. The health preservation step is essential for improving the spinnability of bast fibres and reducing end breakage rate, resulting in better work efficiency and product quality. The process can be applied to various bast fibres such as jute, kenaf, and hemp, and the weight percentage of bast fibres in the blended fibres can range from 20% to 99%.
3. The invention offers several advantages over existing technologies, including the adoption of twice health preservations for blended spinning, which allows for more flexibility in the fibres and improved spinnability, resulting in reduced end breakage rate and enhanced work efficiency and product quality. For instance, when the yarn is 12 s in fineness, the end breakage rate can be reduced to 150-200 times per hour for each machine, compared to the high end breakage rates of up to 300-400 times per hour for each machine in existing technologies.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention provides a method and apparatus for measuring and removing rotational variability from the nip pressure profile of nip presses using covered rolls with imbedded sensors, ensuring a more accurate representation of the true nip pressure being developed.
2. The invention utilizes multiple sensors circumferentially spaced at various cross-directional positions along the sensing roll, allowing the cancellation of rotational variability and the calculation of a more accurate nip pressure profile. Different sensor arrangements provide information on cover wear and roll condition.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention described herein is an apparatus for an ironing board that supports an electrical cord and holds an article. The apparatus includes a clamp, a flexible cord support, and a detachable article holder.
2. The clamp, in a preferred embodiment a "C" shaped design, attaches to the ironing board with an adjusting screw and movable jaw. The flexible cord support pivots and retracts, and the article holder detaches and has a circular base and hoops.
3. The cord support is attached to the clamp and supports the electrical cord above the ironing surface. The article holder is mounted to the clamp and holds articles such as spray starch or beverage containers. The electrical receptacle is carried by the clamp for receiving the plug of the electrical cord.
4. The clamp includes a retainer for the cord support and a second brace for mounting the article holder. The apparatus can be disassembled for storage, with the cord support retracting and the article holder detaching from the second brace.
</summary>

Explanation:

1. The text introduces the invention as an apparatus for an ironing board that supports an electrical cord and holds an article.
2. The clamp is described as a "C" shaped design with a movable jaw and adjusting screw for securing the apparatus to the ironing board. The flexible cord support is pivoted and retractable, and the article holder is detachable and has a circular base and hoops.
3. The cord support is attached to the clamp and supports the electrical cord above the ironing surface. The article holder is mounted to the clamp and holds articles such as spray starch or beverage containers. The electrical receptacle is carried by the clamp for receiving the plug of the electrical cord.
4. The clamp includes a retainer for the cord support and a second brace for mounting the article holder. The apparatus can be disassembled for storage, with the cord support retracting and the article holder detaching from the second brace.

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a buttonhole controlling device for a sewing machine that can effectively form buttonholes in various materials without failure or overlap. (2 sentences)
2. The device includes a foot pad, a travelling assembly with a slidable member, and an adjustable stop. (1 sentence)
3. The travelling assembly moves with the work during sewing and includes a tab to actuate the machine's tripping lever, limiting the length of the buttonhole to the size of the button inserted. (2 sentences)
4. The adjustable stop engages the tripping lever to terminate buttonhole formation, allowing the operator to precisely define the closure point. (1 sentence)
5. The device attaches to the presser bar and operates by controlling the tripping lever, which in turn activates flexible contacts to cause the machine to sew buttonholes. (2 sentences)
6. The operator positions the button between V-notches to establish the buttonhole length, adjusts the stop for perfect closure, and compensates for material differences as needed. (3 sentences)
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes an apparatus for treating a textile web with a liquid, which includes a conveyor, a liquid applicator, a suction device, and a dwell stretch. The conveyor is an endless sieve belt, the applicator applies liquid to the web during motion, the suction device removes the liquid, and the dwell stretch conducts the web in a spread-out condition through a loop.
2. The dwell stretch lengthens the action time of the applied liquid on the substances to be removed, improving the washing effect and maintaining low tension in the textile web. The apparatus is especially advantageous for printed materials, as it avoids stacking and contact with vats.
3. The apparatus can have a compact construction, with the textile web guided back to the sieve belt near the point of return and the suction device disposed near this point. The suction device causes the web to adhere to the belt, reducing longitudinal tensile stresses.
4. The text also describes alternative embodiments of the apparatus, including one with a sieve drum and guide rollers for a meander path and another with freely rotating rollers in an air pass for vertical loops. The apparatus can be used for soilage washing and can have a fastness treatment following the washing operation.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The dry cleaning machine of the present invention includes an air flow system for bringing ambient air into the access opening whenever the door is opened, which is exclusive of the air recirculating system and substantially reduces exhausting the residual solvent vapors from the tubs. This system consists of a separate intake fan and duct with a valve that isolates the intake system from the solvent vapors during normal operation. When the door is opened, the intake fan is energized, and the valve opens, allowing air to be drawn into the access opening and directly into the interposed duct, minimizing the loss of solvent vapors.
2. The dry cleaning machine also includes a solvent flow system for delivering and circulating the solvent during the various stages of the cleaning cycle. During the fill and wash portion, the solvent is pumped from the storage tank into the tubs through filters and recirculated continuously. During the dump and spin portion, the solvent is drained from the tubs and the solvent already in the tubs is dumped back into the storage tank. During the tumble dry with heat portion, the solvent continues to flow through the filtering cycle, but the solvent distributing system is isolated from the circulating drying air. The solvent vapor handling system collects and retains the solvent vapors generated during the fill and wash portions and recovers them during the dry portion of the cycle. The refrigeration system cools the storage tank under all portions of the cycle except the drying portion to maintain the solvent at a predetermined temperature and minimize vaporization.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention introduces a new method and apparatus for forming fine continuous filaments, particularly melt spun nonwoven webs, using an initial quench chamber and a continuous two-dimensional slot across the entire machine width. This design provides good control of cross-machine uniformity and allows for higher quench pressures without structural deflection issues.
2. The system harnesses the positive aspects of both eductive and non-eductive systems while solving problems such as spinning speed limitations, energy consumption, machine element cleanliness, web uniformity, capital costs, and process control. It also incorporates aspects of the meltblown process to improve web formation control.
3. The method and apparatus are extremely flexible and can be varied to accommodate a wide range of materials and operating conditions. The system is useful for forming low basis weight webs from fine polypropylene filaments and producing nonwoven materials for various applications, including sanitary products, limited use garments, surgical drapes, and durable goods. Additionally, the fibers can be collected and used as pillow and cushion stuffing or baled and sold.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The first embodiment describes a sewing machine that uses ultrasonic waves to detect the position of a marker on a work cloth, eliminating the need for physical markers. The machine includes receivers on the sewing machine head and a control system that calculates the position of the marker based on the detected ultrasonic waves.
2. The second embodiment introduces an embroidery unit with receivers on its carriage, allowing the sewing machine to detect the position of the marker even when the embroidery unit is attached. The embroidery unit moves the work cloth to the needle, and the sewing machine calculates the position based on the detected ultrasonic waves.
3. The third embodiment uses an ultrasonic pen with an electromagnetic wave output circuit instead of an ultrasonic wave signal. The sewing machine detects the electromagnetic wave signal and calculates the position of the marker based on the detection timing. This eliminates the need for a cable connecting the pen and the machine.
4. The fourth embodiment adds a receiver to the left surface of the sewing machine pillar and uses it along with the receivers on the head to detect ultrasonic waves. The control system calculates the marker position based on the detection timings of all three receivers.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to methods and preparations for enhancing the utility of cellulosic fabric materials, specifically cotton, linen, or other natural fibers, by adding functional additives. These additives can include ultraviolet protection, anti-bacterial, or other useful properties.
2. The invention addresses the issue of poor stability or performance of known textile articles with functional additives, which rapidly lose their added functional enhancements after several washing cycles. To improve functional durability, the invention uses a preparation comprising ultrafine wool powder or bamboo powder as carriers for functional additives.
3. The ultrafine wool powder or bamboo powder is obtained by pulverizing the respective fibers and forming a suspension. Functional additives, such as zinc oxide, titanium dioxide, or bamboo powder, are then added to the suspension and mixed with an aqueous binder. The resulting preparation is applied to the cellulosic fabric material by printing, padding, or foam application.
4. The ultrafine wool powder or bamboo powder acts as effective carriers for functional additives due to their unique structures. Wool fibers have a helical structure and absorb a large amount of water without feeling wet, while bamboo powder is ultrafine and has good moisture management properties. The use of these carriers enhances the durability of functional enhancements on cellulosic fabric materials.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention describes an automatic quilting machine that uses separate computers or process controllers to control the sewing machine functions and the quilting table movement independently. This allows for easier reprogramming of one element without requiring reprogramming of the entire system.
2. The machine includes a frame quilting machine with a large metal frame, a sewing machine head, and a reprogrammable function for tracing and duplicating patterns. The operator manually draws the desired pattern on a monitor using a computer aided design program, which converts the pattern into machine language and stores it in the computer's memory. The machine then automatically sews the pattern into the fabric by moving the quilting table relative to the sewing needle based on the stored pattern information.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method of making a two-sided nonwoven fabric with a three-dimensional image using hydroentanglement and a support layer or scrim.
2. The fabric is formed from a first and second precursor web, each with a fibrous matrix, which are juxtaposed and hydroentangled on a three-dimensional image transfer device.
3. The first and second fibrous matrices can be made of staple length fibers or substantially continuous filaments, and can be carded and cross-lapped to form precursor webs.
4. A support layer or scrim is interposed between the first and second precursor webs to act as a fiber distribution control layer.
5. The fabric can have a first side with a first fibrous matrix and a second side with a second fibrous matrix, separated by the support layer.
6. The fabric may also include apertures that extend partially or entirely through one or more layers.
7. The fibrous constituents of the first and second precursor webs are prevented from becoming excessively intermingled by the support layer.
8. The fabric can be used in various applications, including home cleaning, personal hygiene, medical, and industrial uses.
9. The present invention provides a durable, three-dimensional image on the fabric that is resistant to abrasion and distortion due to elongation.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention describes a device for feeding a strip of material into a sewing machine and sewing it onto a cut of fabric. It includes a control setup with a stop in the feed path of the strip, which is displaceable out of the path and connectable to the sewing machine for controlling the operation. The stop is carried by a doubled arm lever member that is part of a control means, including a control switch and a setting means for adjusting the position of the stop.
2. The sewing machine includes a bed plate, a slide, a needle plate, and a feed dog. A guide apparatus is provided for guiding a strip of material, which is cut to a predetermined length, into a definite position for sewing. The guide apparatus is mounted with a contact arm that operates on a proximity switch, which in turn controls a solenoid valve to stop the sewing machine when the strip loses contact with the contact arm.
3. The stop is mounted on a two-armed lever, which is biased by a spring and pivots about a pin. The lever has a stop for the leading end of the strip and a switch arm for a proximity switch, which controls a cylinder valve to actuate air cylinder and lower the presser foot of the sewing machine. The device is designed to be simple, rugged, and economical to manufacture.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a method for connecting two tape-shaped knit pieces using a flat knitting machine. (3 sentences)
2. The method involves knitting two tape-shaped pieces on a flat knitting machine with needle beds on both front and rear sides, one or both of which can move in the lateral direction. (3 sentences)
3. When the pieces reach a specified length, the loop portion of one piece is transferred to the needles of the other piece, and the pieces are overlaid and bound off to form a new loop, decreasing the number of loops in the moving side piece. (3 sentences)
4. This process is repeated, decreasing the number of loops in both the moving and fixed side pieces, until the end parts are joined. (3 sentences)
5. The end-to-end joined state of the moving and fixed side pieces is illustrated in FIGS. 2 and 3, with a magnified view in FIGS. 4 and 5. (3 sentences)
6. The knitting diagrams in the principal courses until joining the end parts of the tape-shaped knit fabric are shown in FIGS. 1A-1D, with the courses for arranging the joined ends in FIGS. 1E and 1F. (3 sentences)
7. The rear moving needle bed is moved to transfer the loop of the moving side knit fabric to the fixed side knit fabric, which is then bound off to form a new loop. (3 sentences)
8. The new loop is transferred back to the moving side knit fabric, and the process is repeated to decrease the number of loops in both pieces. (3 sentences)
9. The method can be used to join the end portions of tape-shaped knit fabric in various parts, such as the collar of a sweater, the neck rope portion of a tanktop, or the lower end portion of baseball stockings. (3 sentences)
10. The invention can be realized using a flat knitting machine with multiple knitting needles on a pair of needle beds, with one or both of the needle beds movable in the lateral direction. (3 sentences)
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes a production line for creating band-shaped traction elements with stranded cables made of steel fibers and a plastics material jacket. The line includes reels for unwinding cables, a cleaning system, preheating devices, an extruder, pressure rollers, a cooling trough, and a control apparatus.
2. The extruder uses a thread guide and matrix to sheathe the stranded cables with plastics material. The liquefied plastics material is pressed into the matrix, where the stranded cables pass through, creating a traction element with precise dimensions.
3. The traction elements have a roughened surface and are cooled in a cooling trough before being wound onto a storage roller. The production line is controlled by a system that measures and records dimensions for automatic adjustments.
4. The text also mentions various embodiments of the traction elements, including those with longitudinal grooves, different thicknesses, and asymmetrical cross-sections. The outer contours of the jacket are fixed by pressure rollers, which have a correspondingly structured jacket surface.
5. The production line ensures increased flexibility and improved adhesion between the stranded cables and the plastics material jacket, allowing for the creation of high-quality traction elements suitable for various applications, including lifting and pulling loads.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The invention relates to a new rotary hook arrangement for a lockstitch sewing machine, which includes first and second cams arranged on respective sides of a projection of the bobbin housing of a rotatable hook for controlling the rotation of the bobbin housing with the rotary hook housing.
2. The arrangement includes a spring rod extending between the cams, which cooperates with a projection of the housing, and housing side holding means located on the loop cast-off side of the bobbin housing to hinder the guiding of the needle thread loop and pull-back as little as possible.
3. The needle thread loop can be expanded totally unhindered until its maximum expansion is reached, and then pulled back by the thread take-up lever without touching the front cam or causing significant bending of the spring rod.
4. The slight impediment of the thread movement caused by the bending of the spring rod can be eliminated completely by a capsule release device that gives the bobbin housing a rotational impulse counter to the direction of hook rotation, allowing the needle thread loop to slip through the thread passage gap thus created.
5. The invention provides a simple, rugged, and economical design for a rotary hook arrangement that reduces needle thread tension to a minimum and ensures jerk-free and low-friction motion of the needle thread loop around the bobbin housing.
6. The arrangement includes an eccentric rod and finger that form a capsule release device, which engages with a cutout in the bobbin capsule to rotate the bobbin housing counter to the direction of hook rotation and create a gap for the needle thread loop to pass through unhindered during the pull-back movement.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The text describes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires using electrospinning and four-component inks consisting of a liquid silane, a polymer, an accelerant, and a solvent.
2. Cyclohexasilane (Si 6 H 12 ) is a preferred liquid silane that undergoes ring opening polymerization to form amorphous silicon and then crystalline silicon material.
3. The preferred polymer is poly(methyl methacrylate), and the preferred solvents are toluene, xylene, cyclooctane, 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene, and dichloromethane or mixtures thereof.
4. The preferred accelerant is a polyhydropolysilane, which is completely compatible with the product material and accelerates the polymerization of cyclohexasilane.
5. The electrospinning process involves expelling the viscous solution from a nozzle and exposing it to a high electric field to form continuous fibers that are deposited onto a substrate.
6. The deposited nanowires can be transformed using thermal processing or laser processing to produce polysilane-containing, amorphous silicon-containing, or crystalline silicon-containing materials.
7. Optionally, the transformed fibers can be coated with a coherent, conductive coating, which can be deposited by chemical vapor deposition or solution deposition.
8. The invention also describes a method for producing silicon-based nanowires using five-component inks, which have the same components as four-component inks with the addition of a solid phase.
9. The solid phase can be a metallic particle, a photoactive solid phase, or a reactive compound, and the processing of the five-component inks is typically the same as the processing of the four-component inks.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a tension control arrangement for a spool creel with multiple spool holders.
2. Each spool holder has a tensioning lever, a brake rotor with a braking element, and a pneumatic biasing arrangement.
3. The tensioning lever has a roller that engages the threads and occupies an angular position dependent on thread tension and weight.
4. The biasing arrangement is activated by fluid pressure and influences the tensioning lever, altering thread tension.
5. The thread tension can be centrally set for the entire creel, and the biasing force operates in addition to the weight force on the tensioning lever.
6. The biasing arrangement can be a piston/cylinder assembly that follows the swinging movement of the tensioning lever and prevents thread contamination.
7. The tensioning lever subtends an angle of more than 45° to the horizontal plane, and the working elevation angle of the biasing arrangement attached to the tensioning lever is less than 45°.
8. The biasing arrangement can also operate on a brake shoe that engages a further rotating braking surface under higher fluid pressures for rapid braking.
9. The braking shoe can be held by the tensioning lever, ensuring a simple mode of construction with few additional parts and preventing locking on restart.
10. The arrangement allows for individual and global control of thread tension, with quick braking when the warping machine is shut off.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is a sewing machine detector that detects the position of a sewing needle and the speed of a sewing machine. It is integral with the drive and control elements of the sewing machine.
2. The conventional sewing machine detector, as shown in FIG. 8, includes a sewing machine, motor, belt for transmission of rotation, needle section, control circuit section, detector, and power indicating light.
3. The conventional detector uses an optical fiber type needle position detector, as shown in FIGS. 9-12, which includes a detecting section, optical fiber cable, photoelectric translation processing module section, and electrical connectors.
4. The conventional detector uses reflective discs installed on the shaft of the detecting section to reflect light from the needle UP and needle DOWN position detecting optical fibers, respectively.
5. The conventional detector eliminates the influence of static noise by using optical fibers solely for detection purposes and employing a photoelectric translation processing module section connected to the control circuit section.
6. However, the reflective discs must withstand constant vibration during sewing machine operation and maintain precise optical axes with the optical fibers to ensure accurate detection.
7. The present invention addresses these issues by using flat, sheet-shaped light shielding discs that detect sewing machine speed and needle positions, and are free to rotate relative to the shaft.
8. The optical fiber supporter includes linear optical fiber fixing holes for locking the ends of the light sending and receiving optical fibers, and first and second reflecting portions opposite the end faces of the fibers.
9. The first and second reflecting portions are in opposition, and light transmitted from the light sending optical fibers and reflected by the first reflecting portions passes through the light shielding discs and is reflected by the second reflecting portions to enter the light receiving optical fibers.
10. The present invention provides accurate optical axes, eliminates the need for curved reflecting portions, reduces stress on optical fibers, and simplifies construction by allowing the optical fiber power indicating cable to be run simultaneously with the detection optical fibers.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention simplifies the continuous production of viscose rayon yarns with a high degree of whiteness by combining critical operations, including completion of coagulation, washing with non-alkaline water, and drying.
2. Coagulation is completed by passing time, acid treatment, or a combination of both, until a final coagulation index not higher than 1 is obtained.
3. Washing with non-alkaline water reduces the amounts of sulphur, iron, zinc, and lead on the yarn to specified levels.
4. The process produces a finished yarn with a degree of white not lower than 45, measured by the Hunterlab apparatus.
5. The wash water for this process should have a pH between 4.0 and 5.5 and be free from cations in amounts higher than specified.
6. The process is carried out preferably with spinning speeds not lower than 90 m/min and washing at temperatures between 20° and 30° C for 25-40 seconds.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes a problem in deaerating pulp after oxygen bleaching, which involves reducing foam formed by oxygen entrainment in the pulp mat during washing.
2. Two existing deaeration systems are mentioned: the Deculator process and a radial flow impeller system. Both are expensive and complex.
3. The inventors aimed to create a small, cost-effective deaeration tank that could be placed on top of an oxygen reactor and operate at atmospheric or low pressure.
4. The tank design includes a tangential swirl inducing inlet pipe, an outlet, and no moving parts. It is closed to allow steam or oxygen recovery.
5. The swirl inducing fluid is the filtrate from the washer after the oxygen bleach.
6. The oxygen process involves pumping pulp into a thick stock pump, heating it with steam, mixing it with oxygen, and transferring it to a tower for oxygenation.
7. The oxygenated pulp is then carried to the deaeration tank, where it is deaerated before being washed. The deaerated pulp leaves the tank and enters the washer.
8. The filtrate from the washer is used as swirling fluid in the deaeration tank and is recycled back to an earlier washer or decker as wash water.
9. The deaeration tank is a cylindrical tank with an open top, a flat bottom, and a diameter equal to or slightly larger than the oxygen reactor. It has a height that prevents the swirling slurry from spilling over the sides and is closed if oxygen or steam is being recovered.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes a new composite material concept called BTR (biomimetic tendon-reinforced) composites, obtained through a topology optimization process that maximizes out-plane stiffness.
2. The BTR composite structure includes six fundamental components: tendons/muscles, ribs/bones, joints, flesh, skins, and shell. The fibers are evenly distributed in the matrix material, and materials in tension and compression can be treated differently.
3. The BTR composite can be extended to a three-dimensional lattice structure, which can be fabricated using bent-wire tendon elements and elongated panel stuffer members. The structure can be made of various raw materials, such as steel, carbon-fiber ropes, and carbon fiber/epoxy cover panels.
4. The BTR composite has advantages such as the use of embedded fiber tendons, which act as safety members when a load-carrying tendon breaks, and the ability to stack multiple layers for better out-of-plane performance. The structure can also be made using hollow stuffer members and bent-wire tendons, which simplifies manufacture and may be automated using pick-and-place robotics.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a bedroom cabinet with a flat external surface and the ability to accommodate shelves and devices without projection. (2 sentences)
2. The bedroom cabinet is formed by a hexahedron consisting of an outer casing and an inner casing, with a clearance between them for accommodating boxes or shelves. (2 sentences)
3. The bedroom cabinet has horizontally outwardly projecting flanges on the lower ends of the upper and upper ends of the lower outer casing, allowing for easy assembly and a flat external appearance. (2 sentences)
4. The bedroom cabinet can be provided with spacer members and vents to ensure uniform air flow and sound-proofing. (2 sentences)
5. The bedroom cabinet can be assembled with the lower half of the inner casing received in the lower outer casing, followed by the upper outer casing being fitted on top and secured with a clip member and an ornamental web. (2 sentences)
</summary>

Explanation:

1. The text describes an invention for a bedroom cabinet with a flat external surface and the ability to accommodate shelves and devices without projection.
2. The bedroom cabinet is formed by a hexahedron consisting of an outer casing and an inner casing, with a clearance between them for accommodating boxes or shelves.
3. The bedroom cabinet has horizontally outwardly projecting flanges on the lower ends of the upper and upper ends of the lower outer casing, allowing for easy assembly and a flat external appearance.
4. The bedroom cabinet can be provided with spacer members and vents to ensure uniform air flow and sound-proofing.
5. The bedroom cabinet can be assembled by receiving the lower half of the inner casing into the lower outer casing, followed by the upper outer casing being fitted on top and secured with a clip member and an ornamental web.

<summary>
1. The present invention relates to a portable guard rail support system for use in constructing temporary safety barriers at sites under construction, such as office buildings and high-rise apartments. The system includes a base plate, an upright column, guard rail support brackets, a kick board retaining flange, an angular brace, and a safety tie-off ring. The guard rail supports are secured to the floor or ground surface using expansion anchors or screws, and wooden guard rails and kick boards are secured within the brackets and flange. The system meets safety guidelines and can be assembled and disassembled efficiently.
2. An alternate embodiment includes a concrete-filled steel base for use when anchoring to a floor or ground surface is not possible. The steel base has a groove for slidably receiving the base plate, a channel for receiving the guard rail support components, and a pass-through channel for kick board rails. The guard rail support is securely maintained within the steel base due to its tongue-groove fitting and the weight of the steel base, providing necessary stability and support. The system can also be used in conjunction with a mesh-like fence structure to form a safety barrier. The guard rail supports have at least two rail supporting brackets and a retaining flange for supporting upper and lower wooden rails and kick boards, respectively, to comply with safety regulations. The system is easy to install, disassemble, and reassemble, reducing liability and ensuring durability for repeated use. The guard rail support and assembly can be used in various situations, including the provision of a safety guard rail along the outer drop-off edge of a concrete floor slab during construction.
</summary>

<summary>

1. The present invention is a pulsed power device and method for Enhanced Oil Recovery (EOR). Pulsed power is a rapid release of electrical energy from capacitor banks, which can be harnessed in various industrial applications, including EOR.
2. In an electrohydraulic (EH) mode, pulsed power generates a shock wave that can be used for geophysical exploration, mining, and oil recovery. The physics of the EH shock wave are well understood and documented in U.S. Pat. No. 4,345,650.
3. In an electromagnetic (EM) mode, pulsed power generates a magnetic field that can be used to induce acoustic vibrations in geologic materials, stimulating oil production at multiple scales in the reservoir body.
4. The present invention addresses the limitations of existing acoustic stimulation methods, which are limited to a range of about 1000 feet from the stimulation point due to natural attenuation properties.
5. The invention uses pulsed power to generate high-frequency acoustic stimulation separately from the direct acoustic response of the EH shock wave, extending the effective range of acoustic stimulation.
6. The invention also recognizes the importance of both EH and EM effects for effective oil mobilization and production increase.
7. A preferred embodiment uses a multi-level discharge device to allow sequential firing of multiple sources, extending the effective range of the stimulation up to 5000 to 6000 feet.
8. Another embodiment uses multiple pulse sources in multiple wells to allow electromagnetically-induced vibrations to continue for a longer time, allowing the acoustic pulse to travel further into the formation.
9. The invention can be customized to produce specific frequencies for optimal stimulation by adjusting the inductances of the pulse devices, allowing for a multi-spectral stimulation program.

</summary>

<summary>
1. The text describes a splice (200) for extending the length of a soil reinforcing element (100) in Mechanically Stabilized Earth (MSE) structures.
2. The splice (200) couples one or more grid-strips (202) to the soil reinforcing element (100) to create a composite soil reinforcing element.
3. Each wave plate (208 a,b) of the splice (200) includes transverse protrusions (210) for receiving and seating transverse wires (104, 206) from the soil reinforcing element (100) and grid-strip (202), respectively.
4. The plates (208 a,b) are secured by a connective device (216) extended through aligned perforations (212 a,b,c), and the nut (218) and washer (220) configuration may be used to prevent removal.
5. Multiple splices (200) and grid-strips (202) may be used to extend the length of a single soil reinforcing element (100) and create a composite soil reinforcing element that achieves a desired reinforcing distance from the vertical facing (110).
6. The splice (200) design allows for various configurations of longitudinal and transverse wire spacing, wire disposition, and plate symmetry, providing flexibility for different MSE applications.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention introduces a plow blade design with a fluid passageway and points of fluid ejection, produced using basic manufacturing processes for efficient production. The blade consists of a blade, leading edge sections, point, and a fluid tube. The fluid tube transfers pressurized fluid from the top of the plow into the blade, and the location and length of stitch welds between the blade and leading edge sections define the fluid exit points and volume.
2. The fluid pressure along the blade length varies, and extending the length of the fluid tube towards the bottom of the critical high friction area maximizes the fluid volume at that point. The number of leading edge sections and stitch welds can be adjusted to match specific job requirements, allowing for a nearly infinite variety of configurations in an economic manner. An alternate arrangement has the void or groove formed in the front of the blade instead of the back of the leading edge section. Different nozzle sizes and flow rates can be achieved using a manifold between the blade and leading edge sections, and the fluid tube can be located on the opposite side of the blade for protection.
</summary>

<summary>
1. The present invention is a building system that allows for larger stucco panels without movement control joints, exceeding the current height limit of 2.4 meters and width limit of 4 meters.
2. The system includes a frame or substructure, battens, inner and outer meshes, and a plaster matrix that penetrates both meshes and covers the second mesh.
3. The wall has at least one opening, and the periphery of each opening is further reinforced within the matrix.
4. Preferred materials include metal battens and meshes, and non-metallic second mesh and regional reinforcement.
5. The aim of the invention is to provide a useful choice for the public, comply with NZS3604 and NZS4251 building and plaster codes, and create stucco walled structures with panel rigidity and integrity.
6. The system can cater to various dimensions and shapes, including square or rectangular panels up to 12 meters wide and 4.85 meters high, and larger or smaller panels as well.
7. The method of in situ formation of the reinforced plaster panel includes fixing battens to the support structure, preparing the panel with an inner mesh and formwork, applying plaster, and embedding or part embedding the outer mesh.
8. The invention also includes various components suitable for or of any such product produced by the method, such as window and door assemblies, head and sill flashings, and lattice or perforate reinforcement.
</summary>
